p: On a per ha basis, GHG emissions for major food crops in India are generally lower than those in Europe and North America, with GHG emissions for cereals 2–3-fold greater in Europe (2000–3000 kg CO 2eq ha −1 yr −1) ( Carlton et al., 2012). A study in Canada estimated GHG emissions for spring wheat of 600 and 1400 kg CO 2eq ha −1 yr −1 ( Gan et al., 2012). GHG emissions for potatoes and peas show a similar range in Europe of ∼3000 kg CO 2eq ha −1 yr −1 and ∼660 kg CO 2eq ha −1 yr −1, respectively ( Carlton et al., 2012). A Swedish study reported GHG emissions of wheat of 0.2–0.6 kg CO 2eq kg −1 production ( Röös et al., 2011); the calculated GHG emissions for wheat in India are towards the lower end of that range. A comparison of rice production in a Chinese study showed a range from 2000 kg CO 2eq ha −1 yr −1 for upland rice up to 20000 kg CO 2eq ha −1 yr −1 for paddy rice production, and similar values have been reported for Indian rice ( Li et al., 2006).
